item.description:
A relation is a structure that is used to represent the relationships between elements

Category of relations

  • Binary relations
  • N-ary relations

Binary Relations

A binary relation R from the set ð´ to the set ðµ is a subset of ð´ Ã— ðµ.

R is a set of ordered pairs in the form (ð‘Ž, ð‘) where ð‘Ž is from ð´ and ð‘ is from ðµ.

a R b denotes (ð‘Ž, ð‘) âˆˆ ð‘…, called ð‘Ž is related to ð‘ by R

Functions and Relations

  • Are all the functions relations? Yes
  • Are all relations functions? No

Relation on the Set

  • A relation on the set is a relation from ð´ to ð´.

Properties of Relations

Reflexive

A relation ð‘… on a set ð´ is called reflexive if (ð‘Ž, ð‘Ž) âˆˆ ð‘… for every element ð‘Ž âˆˆ A

Symmetric

A relation ð‘… on a set ð´ is called symmetric if (ð‘, ð‘Ž) âˆˆ ð‘… whenever (ð‘Ž, ð‘) âˆˆ R

Anti-symmetric

relation ð‘… on a set ð´ is called anti-symmetric if whenever (ð‘Ž, ð‘) âˆˆ ð‘… and (ð‘, ð‘Ž) âˆˆ ð‘…, then ð‘Ž = ð‘

Transitive

A relation ð‘… on a set ð´ is called transitive if whenever (ð‘Ž, ð‘) âˆˆ ð‘… and (ð‘, ð‘) âˆˆ ð‘…, then (ð‘Ž, ð‘) âˆˆ ð‘…

Combining Relations

The composite of ð‘… and ð‘† (ð‘† â—¦ ð‘…): consisting of all ordered pairs (ð‘Ž, ð‘) where ð‘Ž âˆˆ ð´, and ð‘ âˆˆ ð¶ if there exists ð‘ such that (ð‘Ž, ð‘) âˆˆ ð‘… and (ð‘, ð‘) âˆˆ ð‘†.

E.g.,
â–ª ð´ = {1}, ðµ = {0, 1}, ð¶ = {2, 3}
â–ª ð‘… = {(1, 0), (1, 1)} (a relation from ð´ to ðµ)
â–ª ð‘† = {(0, 2), (1, 3)} (a relation from ðµ to ð¶)
â–ª ð‘† â—¦ ð‘… = {(1, 2), (1, 3)}

Powers of a Relation

Let ð‘… be a relation on the set ð´. The powers ð‘…ð‘› for integer ð‘› with ð‘› > 0 are defined recursively by $R^1 = R$
$R^{n}=R^{n-1}â—¦R$

Theorem: The relation ð‘… on a set ð´ is transitive if and only if ð‘…^ð‘› âŠ† ð‘… for ð‘› = 1, 2, 3, â‹¯

ð‘›-ary Relations

  • Let ð´1, ð´2, â€¦ , ð´ð‘› be sets.
  • An ð‘›-ary relation on these sets is a subset of ð´1 Ã— ð´2 Ã— â‹¯ Ã— ð´ð‘›
  • Domain: ð´1 Ã— ð´2 Ã— â‹¯ Ã— ð´ð‘›
  • Degree: n

Relations and Database

  • Currently, the most commonly used databases are relational databases.
  • Each database consists of multiple relations.
  • Each relation is presented as a table.

Operations on n-ary Relations

Selection operator ðœŽ:

  • ð‘›-ary relation ð‘…
  • condition ð‘
  • Selection operator ðœŽð‘: maps ð‘… to an ð‘›-ary relations ð‘‡, where all the tuples in ð‘‡ satisfy the condition ð‘.
    i.e. ðœŽ_{ð‘šð‘Žð‘—ð‘œð‘Ÿ}=“ð¶ð‘œð‘šð‘ð‘¢ð‘¡ð‘’ð‘Ÿ ð‘†ð‘ð‘–ð‘’ð‘›ð‘ð‘’” ðºð‘Ÿð‘Žð‘‘ð‘’ð‘…ð‘’ð‘ð‘œð‘Ÿð‘¡ = {(ð½ð‘œâ„Žð‘›,001,ð¶ð‘œð‘šð‘ð‘¢ð‘¡ð‘’ð‘Ÿ ð‘†ð‘ð‘–ð‘’ð‘›ð‘ð‘’, 3.5)}

Projection operator ðœ‹:

  • the input relation is on ð‘› tuples (ð‘Ž1, ð‘Ž2, â‹¯ , ð‘Žð‘›) ,
  • the output relation is on ð‘š tuples (ð‘Žð‘–_1,ð‘Žð‘–_2, â‹¯ , ð‘Žð‘–_ð‘š), ð‘š < ð‘›.
  • Projection operator ðœ‹ð‘–1,ð‘–2,â‹¯,ð‘–ð‘š: removes the tuples not in the ð‘š-tuple (ð‘Žð‘–1ð‘Žð‘–2, â‹¯ , ð‘Žð‘–ð‘š) list i.e. ðœ‹_{ð‘›ð‘Žð‘šð‘’,ðºð‘ƒð´} (ðºð‘Ÿð‘Žð‘‘ð‘’ð‘…ð‘’ð‘ð‘œð‘Ÿð‘¡) = {(ð½ð‘œâ„Žð‘›, 3.5 ),( ð‘‡ð‘œð‘›ð‘¦, 3.2 ),( ð½ð‘œð‘›ð‘Žð‘ , 3.3)}

Equivalence Relations

  • A relation on a set ð´ is called an equivalence relation if it is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive. Let ð‘… be an equivalence relation on ð´.

Equivalent class

Equivalent class -> Equivalent relations

Partition

  • All the equivalent classes obtained from ð´ through an equivalent class are either same or disjoint.
  • These disjoint classes are subsets of ð´.
  • The union of these subsets is ð´.
  • These subsets are called a partition of A In general, (ð´1, ð´2, â‹¯ , ð´ð‘›) is a partition of ð´ if:
  1. ð´ð‘– â‰  âˆ… for all 1 â‰¤ ð‘– â‰¤ ð‘›
  2. ð´ð‘– âˆ© ð´ð‘— = âˆ… for all 1 â‰¤ ð‘–,ð‘— â‰¤ ð‘›
  3. ð´1 âˆª ð´2 âˆª â‹¯ âˆª ð´ð‘› = A

Theorem: Let ð‘… be an equivalence relation on a nonempty set ð´.

#include<string>
#include<algorithm>
using namespace std;
#define For(a,b,c) for(int a=b;a<c;a++)
const int N=1e6;

string op;
int t;
int n,m;
#define ios ios::sync_with_stdio(false);cin.tie(0);cout.tie(0);
int change(int p,int q){
 For(i,0,n){
 int x=a[i].second>>p&1;
 if(a[i].first=="AND")q&=x;
 else if(a[i].first=="OR")q|=x;
 else {q^=x;}
 }
 return q;
}
int main(){
 ios
 cin>>n>>m;
 For(i,0,n){
 cin>>a[i].first;
 cin>>a[i].second;
 }
 int pre=0,aft=0;
 For(i,0,30){
 int p=29-i;
 int pos1=change(p,0);
 int pos2=change(p,1);
 if(pre+(1<<p)<=m && pos2>pos1){
 pre+=1<<p;
 aft+=pos2<<p;
 }
 else aft+=pos1<<p;
 }
 cout<<aft<<endl;
}

 ios
 int n,p,h,m,a,b;
 cin>>n>>p>>h>>m;
 while(m--){
 cin>>a>>b;
 if(a>b)swap(a,b);
 if(used.count(make_pair(a,b)))continue;
 d[a+1]--;
 d[b]++;
 used.insert(make_pair(a,b));
 }
 d[0]=h;
 FOR(i,1,n+1){
 d[i]+=d[i-1];
 cout<<d[i]<<'\n';
 }
 return 0;
}
